code: function transfer(address _to, uint _value) onlyPayloadSize(2 * 32) { if(ifDestory(msg.sender)) throw; balances[msg.sender] = balances[msg.sender].sub(_value); balances[_to] = balances[_to].add(_value); Transfer(msg.sender, _to, _value); }
reason: The function 'transfer' uses a conditional throw based on the return of 'ifDestory(msg.sender)'. This could lead to Denial of Service (DoS) if an attacker can control the 'destoryAddress' or the sender address to always cause the function to revert, thus preventing legitimate transfers.

code: function transferFrom(address _from, address _to, uint _value) onlyPayloadSize(3 * 32) { if(ifDestory(msg.sender)) throw; var _allowance = allowed[_from][msg.sender]; balances[_to] = balances[_to].add(_value); balances[_from] = balances[_from].sub(_value); allowed[_from][msg.sender] = _allowance.sub(_value); Transfer(_from, _to, _value); }
reason: Similar to the 'transfer' function, 'transferFrom' also uses a conditional throw based on 'ifDestory(msg.sender)'. An attacker controlling the 'destoryAddress' or the 'msg.sender' address can cause the transfer to always fail, preventing legitimate transfers and potentially locking down the functionality of the token.

The function 'setDestoryAddress' sets the address which can trigger the 'ifDestory' check, leading to potential DoS as described above. However, this function is not protected by any access control, meaning that any user can call it and set the 'destoryAddress', therefore gaining the power to disrupt the 'transfer' and 'transferFrom' operations.
